answers.answer: Hi. Just thought I would let you know that a low B12 can cause tingling sensations like you described. All they need to do is draw some blood to check your vitamin levels.  So it's def. worth checking. You can google vitamin b12 deficiencies for more info. Don't give up to figure out the problem. I know all to well that it sometimes takes doctors too long to diagnois a problem.  I will pray for you that it is nothing more serious.  Try to relax and know you can get through anything. ~Praying for a cure~

question: I am a 33 year old male.  Over the last week I have started to experience mild tingling in my left arm/hand and leg/foot.  Also on the left side of my scalp.  I do not have pain, headache, loss of vision, hearing, numbness, dizzyness, or muscle weakness.  I have had 3 inner ear infections (I think) in the last 4 years.  The tingling is intermitent in my arm and leg and the top left side of my scalp just kind of feels like something is sitting on it.  I met with my Doctor and he did a basic exam, looking at my eyes, ears, throat and examining my back and neck.  He also listened to my lungs.  He did not seem overly concerned, but ordered an MRI of the neck and head to make sure.I injured my neck in high school and had an MRI and physical therapy about 3 years ago.  Before therapy, I was experiencing strong pain/numbness in my neck and left shoulder.  The MRI showed bone spurs.  I have only had a few issues with that since therapy.I lift weights about 3-4 times per week, and do fairly heavy vertical press weight with my shoulders in particular.  I do not have a family history of cancer, heart attack, or stroke.  My Grandfather does have type 2 diabetes.Hopefully this is enough info.  I am very worried, but don't know if I should be.  I of course am picturing the worst - brain tumor, ms, stroke.  Can you offer me some words of wisdom or comfort?  What might I be experiencing?  Thank you!!
title: Tingling in scalp and left arm/leg
